{"blocks":[{"key":"e4a4c","text":"Connect CMOS cameras and LED drivers to the TTL generating device (see the associated protocol) using BNC and Hirose cables. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2r2u9","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9s0jo","text":"Remove the 493_574 cube insert (top right cube attached to objective) and unscrew the cap (SM1CP2) that blocks stray light from the corresponding DFM1. Place a white non reflective surface in front of the exposed hole. Turn on the 565nm LED. This light should be projected onto the white surface, ideally a long distance away. Turn on the other LEDs and one at a time, align the angle of propagation of the 415nm and 470nm LEDs to the 565nm LED by adjusting the collimators. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":91,"length":6},{"style":"bold","offset":146,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1n6pb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"11mij","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3ulko","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"guid":"2525DABA081511EFA77C0A58A9FEAC02","height":461,"id":559855,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"7rgs2\",\"text\":\"Align LEDs\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"alighnment2.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qf5bb7xi7.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/tczrb7xi7.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/tczqb7xi7.webp","width":346}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3mt4a","text":"Align fiber bundle and excitation light. The X,Y position of the fiber bundle must be centered on the path of excitation light – otherwise some fibers will be dimmer and others brighter. Insert the 493_574 cube and turn on the 470nm LED to highest power. A bright \"hotspot\" should be visible projected on the white surface. The shadow of the fiber bundle should also be visible – use the X and Y knobs on the CXYZ05 to center the fiber bundle at this bright hotspot. Do this for each LED. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":409,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2pat3","text":"Set camera settings using Spinview and bring fiber bundle into focus adjusting Z on the CXYZ05. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":88,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cai22","text":"Set LED drivers to Trigger mode and test triggering of TTL generating device  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

description: {"blocks":[{"key":"5qot8","text":"Frame-projected independent fiber photometry (FIP) is a method to measure fluorescent sensor signals through optical fibers implanted in living animals, using a camera to record video of the fiber faces. To precisely control timings of excitation and camera frame acquisition for FIP, and of other external stimulation apparatus (e.g. LEDs for photo-stimulation), we use a Teensy 4.1 microcontroller, which generates voltage pulses without relying on continuous communication with the operating system of the experimental computer for timing. This protocol is for the 3 excitation LED + 2 collection CMOS cameras design. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3hnl6","text":"Triggering-controlling software (an Arduino sketch) and data aquisition software (a Bonsai workflow) can be found in an associated github repository.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"1ka71","text":"Teensy 4.1 only provides ~3.3V. If the device you want to trigger requires 5V (or more), the voltage needs to be up-regulated.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3ulo0","text":"Based on acquisition frame rate and the CMOS cameras to be used, set the acquisition parameters in the .ino sketch.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6c90o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"x2z7q","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"nwjck","text":"When acquisition is 60Hz (20Hz for each channel) with sufficiently fast CMOS sensors (e.g. FLIR, BFS-U3-20S4M-C), an example parameter set could be:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5fia4","text":"ExpT = 15650 μs","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9nbmt","text":"Δt1 = 666 μs","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ech7i","text":"Δt2 = 300 μs","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"31ao1","text":"Δt3 = 50 μs","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f8477","text":"ExpT+ Δt1+Δt2+Δt3 = 16666 μs (= 1/60 s)","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"t8ep","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"27hkv","text":"For better signal, Δt1/Δt2/Δt3 should be minimized to make the exposure time longer. If they are too short, however, the camera will not be able to unload the data (when Δt1 is too short) or LED instability at the onsets (when Δt2 is too short) would lead to periodic noise generation. Based on excitation light sources and CMOS models, optimize these parameters empirically.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"AC0C9185345711EEAFD10A58A9FEAC02","height":556,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"2vl8a\",\"text\":\"Fig2.
